newsitem.title: USA: USDA sees possible record U.S. soybean crop.
newsitem.headline: USDA sees possible record U.S. soybean crop.

text.p: Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said on Monday that good weather this growing season could push U.S. soybean production to an all-time record.
"If we have normal weather, it could give us the highest production ever," Glickman said in a speech at an agriculture policy conference.

He spoke after the USDA announced estimates earlier Monday showing U.S. farmers plan to plant 68.8 million acres of soybeans this year, the most since 1980. "Soybeans was perhaps the big surprise," Glickman said, adding that the USDA estimate was "above and beyond" any industry expectations.
The report also showed that U.S. soybean stocks have fallen to a 20-year low, Glickman said.
"Prices can be expected to remain strong although the prospects of a record crop could take some steam out of the market," he said.
U.S. farmers are responding to strong global demand for corn and soybeans and reducing their crops of wheat and cotton this year, he said.
"By and large, things look pretty good out there," Glickman said, referring to the overall outlook for U.S. farm production this year.
Glickman also said the sign-up for the Conservation Reserve Program, which ended last Friday, was "very strong."
The department will announce later this week how many acres were bid for the program, he said.

"The new program will no longer be used to control supply and demand," he said. "From here on out, it remains and is, a conservation program. It will focus on preventing soil erosion, protecting wildlife habitat."

On the controversial issue of downsizing the USDA, Glickman said he had not approved any additional reorganization plans. "As I told Congress and others, there will be no surprises," he said. "There has been nothing implemented or formally approved" pending the budget negotiation process, he said.

"The bottom line here is to figure out functionally what we want these offices do before we decide how many and in what capacity they will be around," he said. USDA officials plan to meet with White House and congressional leaders during the next four to six weeks to talk about the role of USDA's farm offices throughout the nation.
